title: [Experiment] Follow up: Display known fields in locked fields within trial sign up form (remove_known_trial_form_fields_v2)
description:
# Overview
This experiment is a follow up to a previous experiment https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/team-tasks/-/issues/281 where we removed known fields from the SaaS trial form. The hypothesis being that we will increase the form submission rate by reducing the number of fields the user has to submit to complete the form.

 
# New hypothesis
Users are concerned about submitting a form that starts with company information like "company name" "number of employees" as it implies they are submitting the form on behalf of their company and not as an individual person/user of GitLab. Users would value seeing their previously submitting information while still enjoying a shorter form to submit. 


# Experiment design
To test this hypothesis we will test two designs vs the control experience as seen below: 
 

| Control | Non-editable group | Welcoming group |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
|![image](/uploads/3c1dc7e3e8cc03d0ab17386c9550c868/image.png) |![image](/uploads/a806c6ffc806b33c465b0e7506abd487/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/7f220e659e8cda7e39a91025cc93e72c/image.png) |
| Default form with prefilled values | Greyed-out prefilled values | Copy change + hiding prefilled values |
 
However, in this previous test shown above the control outperformed the experiment with statistically significant results, a full recap can be viewed here https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/team-tasks/-/issues/281#note_540419469. 

# Oldest design 

| Control | Experiment |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/66b7673b06808d8fa053cb84b46af415/image.png) | ce![image](/uploads/c322b1043cb8446660ff31a15aea3352/image.png)l |
  

# Older design

| **Variant - Control** | **Variant - Non-editable** | **Variant - Welcoming** |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/87b11e50dcd74c62e54c42b1d56c1c95/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/618df32da423bc4e9c531adbadcd9a32/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/ba9f376889428d3a4785f9a898079c5c/image.png) |
  
# Experiment tracking

* Track user_ids of users in the control and experiment groups
* Users in the control should have known values in first, last name fields
* Users in each experiment (one of three variant groups shown above) group should have values in the first, last name fields
* For both the experiment and control groups (one of three variant groups shown above) track the unique views and the unique submissions of the form
 
Note this tracking is the same as the tracking we used in the initial experiment with the only change being that we need to also track if the user/namespace was included in the control or variant 1 (non-editable) or variant 2 (variant - welcoming)

title: Diffs are not paginated when "Show whitespace changes" is unchecked
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Diffs should be batched in groups and returned to the diffs view so that we can load large merge requests quicker. Unfortunately, when "Show whitespace changes" is unchecked, diffs are not batched but returned all at once. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to https://gitlab.com/phikai/unreasonably-large/-/merge_requests/2/diffs
1. Open your network tab and search for `batch`
1. When "Show whitespace changes" is checked, you should see multiple requests to the `diffs_batch.json` endpoint that each return only 5 diff files
1. When "Show whitespace changes" is unchecked, you will only see 1 request which takes a very long time and locks up the browser. If the request is able to succeed, you will see all of the diff files returned in this response

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Unchecking "show whitespace changes" returns all diff files at the same time, with only 1 request to `diffs_batch.json`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Unchecking "show whitespace changes" should return only 5 diff files at a time, with multiple requests to `diffs_batch.json` being required

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Introduce mobile styles for on-call schedules and escalation policies
description:
We've introduced the MVC for on-call schedules and will soon introduce the MVC for escalation policies. We haven't officially tackled mobile views for those pages yet. Mobile views will become increasingly important, especially when we introduce paging.

In this issue we'll introduce basic mobile frameworks for on-call schedules and escalation policies.

Here's how mobile on-call schedules look currently in the product:

| Ex 1 | Ex 2 | Ex 3 (everything starts breaking) | Ex 4 (modals) | Ex 5 (modals) |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2021-04-06_at_9.00.13_AM](/uploads/c762a0810552ab7adf28aeaa59f86a75/Screen_Shot_2021-04-06_at_9.00.13_AM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2021-04-06_at_9.01.07_AM](/uploads/378de5db80f7e9b03a3767c5f1d75069/Screen_Shot_2021-04-06_at_9.01.07_AM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2021-04-22_at_10.40.02_AM](/uploads/a7b85100064063ba756a96426d0949a4/Screen_Shot_2021-04-22_at_10.40.02_AM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2021-04-22_at_10.40.47_AM](/uploads/76785044458ce5e4622f4baa4154ca35/Screen_Shot_2021-04-22_at_10.40.47_AM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2021-04-22_at_10.41.24_AM](/uploads/e85604b7e4f6dee2fb1716762e02e8ca/Screen_Shot_2021-04-22_at_10.41.24_AM.png) |

### Goals for V1

Primarily, we want to have these views break a little less than they do now :sweat_smile: 

Beyond that - users will likely be viewing and editing schedule rotations on mobile, for instance to see who is on-call in the upcoming shifts, or when replacing someone who is/will be on-call soon. There are two scenarios in which we expect this is likely to occur:

- A manager is double checking to ensure there is proper coverage of on-call shifts (for example, if a team member has called in sick or the manager wants to add someone or change someone around, etc). 
- An IC going in to verify and/or edit their own on-call shift.

As a first pass, we will support these two scenarios by ensuring the calendar content is the primary content on the page, and putting any "supportive content" out of immediate view. 

Additional steps to support these scenarios:
- In places where we have multiple buttons on larger screen-sizes that are unlikely to be used on mobile, combining them into a single button (ex - putting the edit and delete schedules behind a single "more actions" button)
- Putting the rotation label and the rotation buttons in separate rows, so the rotation participants can take the full width of the screen.
- Rather than displaying a full 24 hours or a full two weeks as we do on larger screens, only displaying _either_ an hourly or a weekly view. Limiting those views to 8 hours in the hourly view, or 7 days in the weekly view.

### Designs for On-Call Schedules

Following general mobile design patterns in the product, we could introduce mobile states for the on-call schedule page:

| Schedule | Schedule dropdown | View dropdown | Rotation action dropdown | Add schedule button (when it's added| Modal example | Empty state |
| ------ | ------ |  ------ | ------ |  ------ | ------ | ------ |
|![Schedule](/uploads/61a4fc8f87630950e9624b6bb4e275ca/Schedule.png) | ![Schedule_dropdown](/uploads/a0213a72b6565488368d94f7c4e4574e/Schedule_dropdown.png) | ![View_dropdown](/uploads/ab4e2e6dfefbb26d9535971339d7fb15/View_dropdown.png) | ![Rotation_action_dropdown](/uploads/2f95fdc464b17272ac35c869e267bb89/Rotation_action_dropdown.png) | ![Add_a_schedule_button__when_it_s_added_](/uploads/ae4a7c13243ae1c265dee91b5e1434e3/Add_a_schedule_button__when_it_s_added_.png) |![Modal_pattern](/uploads/a05c05698400c5ac5dd4bead9fd5f748/Modal_pattern.png) | ![Empty_state](/uploads/2c6049c74351f401029d046562c5cda1/Empty_state.png)|

### Designs for Escalation Policies

Following these patterns, we could also introduce mobile states for the escalation policies page:

| Escalation policy | Modal example | Empty state |
| ------ | ------ |  ------ |
| ![Escalation](/uploads/0cb93cb450fb194c9ea74defb7439352/Escalation.png) | ![Modal_designs](/uploads/98c2ba323ea45a243da0443a2d5ae412/Modal_designs.png)|![Empty_state](/uploads/847a9ba9f0d5170b04382b919d7fc361/Empty_state.png) |

[Figma file](https://www.figma.com/file/v7MuRq550tDL5ZRFVLp9bu/Mobile-designs-on-call-schedules-gitlab-com-and-327021?node-id=912%3A44969)

### Ideas for future improvements

When discussing this, we talked about how it would be nice to see who is on call now and/or when "I" am next on call. This seems like it could be nice to have on all screen sizes, but that it might also be challenging to figure out how to display, since you can have many rotations and many schedules on a single page. So, a single call-out likely will not work. Have created an issue to look at that piece separately.

title: SAML enforcement by default if enabled
description:
<!-- This issue template can be used a great starting point for feature requests. The last section "Release notes" can be used as a summary of the feature and is also required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated using the release post item generator:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator. The remaining sections are the backbone for every feature in GitLab. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve 

When analyzing SAML usage data, I found that [more than half of the groups using group SAML don't enforce it](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/636494/Dev:-Manage:-Access-SAML-SSO-Usage?widget=11401535&udv=0). This was unexpected as I believe that if a customer goes through setup they would want to enforce it to make sure their group is protected.

We previously did not make it default to avoid user lockout. We have enabled [owners to access the groups outside of SAML](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/211962) so we have mitigated this risk. 

### Proposal 

Can we start by making enforcement the default behavior for new groups. If SSO is enabled, then we automatically toggle the two enforcement toggles below (UI and Git enforcement). The user can choose to disable it if they want. 

Should we present a warning if they disable it? "Disabling SAML enforcement may allow users to access your group without authenticating through your SAML provider". 

![Frame_64](/uploads/3bc9ce95bff5b0d83a7fde9ee30f59e4/Frame_64.png)

### Implementation plan

#### Default the `Enforce SSO-only authentication for web activity for this group.` toggle to `on`

* Add `self.enforced_sso = true` to [ee/app/models/saml_provider.rb#L108](/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/models/saml_provider.rb#L108)
* Update spec at [ee/spec/models/saml_provider_spec.rb#L124](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/spec/models/saml_provider_spec.rb#L124)

#### Display a message if enforcement isn't enabled

* Add "**Warning** - Disabling SAML enforcement may be a security risk." message to [app/views/groups/saml_providers/_form.html.haml#L16](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/views/groups/saml_providers/_form.html.haml#L16).
* In the [`updateToggles` method](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/saml_providers/saml_settings_form.js#L118), show/hide the message.
* Update specs in [ee/spec/frontend/saml_providers/saml_settings_form_spec.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/spec/frontend/saml_providers/saml_settings_form_spec.js)

#### Convert toggles to checkboxes

- Change `f.hidden_field` to `f.check_box` in [app/views/groups/saml_providers/_form.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/views/groups/saml_providers/_form.html.haml) and remove any unnecessary toggle markup. 
- Remove [`setupToggleButtons`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/saml_providers/saml_settings_form.js#L4) as it will no longer be needed.
- Update any selectors in failing feature/QA specs

title: Perform Audit - identify and address underperforming SQL queries (Composition Analysis)
description:
## Audit the codebase in your area

Please complete this [audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325440#instructions). Things to look for:

* Known n+1 issues
* Read-only queries that can be redirected to read-only replicas
* Opportunities for caching data on frequent reads
* Lazy loading data ([example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324003#note_526293202))
* Removing or not exact caching costly but not super needed information totally or through a feature flag (so we only turn it off for .com for the time being). See [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325440#note_534199203) below.
* **Unknown unknowns:** please think creatively about ways to find and optimize queries, or otherwise relieve DB load!
  * **[Use Elasticsearch with PostgreSQL slow logs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/runbooks/-/merge_requests/3361)** to collect more information when you have suspicious queries.
  * Look at this [dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/api-rails-controller/api-rails-controller?viewPanel=2155933118&orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-controller=Grape&var-action=All) for endpoints that have a high number of SQL calls

## Audit your Current Backlog

You might have already identified some of the issues above and captured them as issues. Please assign those to team members and if possible add them to the overall Epic.

## Resources for Team Members to use

[Query optimizations - Tips, Tools and Links on what to look for](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325480#note_534758120)

## Audited controllers

Dependency Scanning
   - [x] [Dependency List](#note_579356589)
   - [x] [Dependencies API](#note_579356897)

License Compliance
   - [x] [Licenses List](#note_579358161)
   - [x] [Managed Licenses API](#note_579358720)

[Configuration](#note_579359592)
- [x] Toggling of the auto-fix feature

See [thread](#note_579260587) where we came up to this list.

## Outcome
1. Issues of improvement opportunities
   1. Query optimization
   1. Caching
   1. Moving to read-only replica
   1. Query frequency reduction
   1. Lazy loading
   1. Result truncating (example: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325440#note_534199203)
1. If nothing is discovered as list above, please briefly summarize the queries reviewed in this issue for the record so we won't have to review them again in the future.

When complete, please add a check mark in the *[Original Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325440)*.

title: Report overall per-table progress of primary key migration
description:
In order to simplify getting status updates on the primary key migration effort, we'd like to report the overall progress of the primary key migration to prometheus.

That is, we follow this pattern:

1. We keep track of the estimated relation size at the beginning of the migration https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326994
1. We continuously report the % complete when a job completes

The % complete can be calculated by the following ratio:
1. Sum of the batch sizes from previous, completed jobs
1. Estimated relation size at the beginning of the migration

epic.title: Address Primary Key overflow risk for tables with an integer PK

title: Refer to expired SSH keys in the past tense
description:
### Problem

The `User Settings > SSH Keys` always uses `Expires:` to prefix the expiration date. 

This becomes really confusing when a key has expired, as it seems as if the date hasn't passed yet.

For example: `Expires: 2021-03-01` vs `Expired: 2021-03-01`

### Proposed solution

Prefix the past date with `Expired:` for expired keys.

![image](/uploads/1545862c90e3c332268957e6f43eb601/image.png)

### Implementation outline

```bash
# app/views/profiles/keys/_key.html.haml
- s_('Profiles|Expires:')
+ key.expired? ? s_('Profiles|Expired:') : s_('Profiles|Expires:')
```

epic.title: Improve PAT & SSH credential inventory & management

title: Keep track of reltuples at the time of creating a migration
description: In order to report progress later, we'd like to keep track of `pg_class.reltuples` for the table an question when we create the migration record. This is necessary because over time, `pg_class.reltuples` is going to deviate and may turn not representative for the total number of tuples we need to update. This is because at the same time as creating the migration, we install sync triggers to keep new data automatically in sync - hence we don't need to touch those tuples with the migration.

epic.title: Improve background migrations for primary key conversions

title: Remove GitLab WAF related columns from database
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

More information about deprecation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/271276

We have to remove all columns that were used in GitLab WAF feature, as they are no longer used from %14.0. It is important to gradually remove these columns across multiple releases and do it according to the process described here: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/what_requires_downtime.html#dropping-columns

## Relevant links

- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5696)
- [Database guideline for dropping a column](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/what_requires_downtime.html#dropping-columns)

## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [-] Documentation
- [-] Feature flag:
- [-] Performance:
- [x] Testing:
  - [x] Test if Ingress can be installed and is working properly,
  - [x] Test if Fluentd can be installed and is working properly


## Implementation plan

* [x] ~database drop columns `modsecurity_enabled`, `modsecurity_mode` from `clusters_applications_ingress` table,
* [x] ~database drop column `waf_log_enabled` from `clusters_applications_fluentd`,
* [x] ~database remove `index_clusters_applications_ingress_on_modsecurity` index

title: Remove GitLab WAF related models/services and workers
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

More information about deprecation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/271276

We have to remove all code related to GitLab WAF feature from `gitlab-org/gitlab` codebase.

## Relevant links

- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5696)

## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [-] Documentation
- [-] Feature flag:
- [-] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:
  - [ ] Test if Ingress can be installed and is working properly,
  - [x] Test if Fluentd can be installed and is working properly


## Implementation plan

* [x] ~backend remove `modsecurity_enabled`, `modsecurity_mode`, `waf_log_enabled` from permitted params in method `cluster_application_params` in `app/controllers/clusters/applications_controller.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove extending log path to modsecurity logs in `path_to_logs` method and remove condition `waf_log_enabled` in method `has_at_least_one_log_enabled?` in `app/models/clusters/applications/fluentd.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove all consts that are matching `MODSECURITY_*`, default value definitions for `modsecurity_enabled`, `modsecurity_mode`; `modsecurity_mode` enum; `modsecurity_not_installed`, `modsecurity_enabled`
`modsecurity_disabled` scopes; `specification`, `modsecurity_config_content`, `modsecurity_config_file_path`, `modsecurity_snippet_content` methods and modify `content_values` to not merge `specification` in `app/models/clusters/applications/ingress.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove `with_enabled_modsecurity` scope from `app/models/clusters/cluster.rb`,
* [x] ~backend remove `modsecurity_enabled`, `modsecurity_mode`, `waf_log_enabled` from exposed fields in `app/serializers/cluster_application_entity.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove `waf_log_enabled` from `FLUENTD_KNOWN_ATTRS` constant, and references to `modsecurity_enabled` and `modsecurity_mode` in `expose` method in app/services/clusters/applications/base_service.rb
* [x] ~backend remove `ingress_mod_security_help_path` from `status_path` variable in app/views/clusters/clusters/show.html.haml
* [x] ~backend remove `web_application_firewall_metrics_worker` from `Settings.cron_jobs` in `config/initializers/1_settings.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove `:waf_anomalies` from `security` namespace in `ee/config/routes/project.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove `::Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::IngressModsecurityCounter` from `usage_data_counters` method from `ee/lib/ee/gitlab/usage_data.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove `ingress_modsecurity_usage` method, `ingress_modsecurity_enabled` key from `features_usage_data_ce` method and `ingress_modsecurity_usage` from `system_usage_data` method in `lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove `modsecurity_blocking`, `modsecurity_logging`, `modsecurity_disabled`, `modsecurity_not_installed` traits and settings value for `modsecurity_enabled` from `spec/factories/clusters/applications/helm.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove specs for `counts.ingress_modsecurity_logging` joined relations in `spec/lib/gitlab/usage/metrics/names_suggestions/generator_spec.rb`
* [x] ~backend remove specs for `ingress_modsecurity_usage` in `spec/lib/gitlab/usage_data_spec.rb`

title: Remove GitLab WAF feature from Ingress/fluentd/threat monitoring statistic pages
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

* **statistics** ![statistics](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/e9835ce006a668703f425e7a79af28bf/statistics.png)

title: Settings search should not appear in billings page
description:
# Problem
Currently, the settings search bar appears on the in-app billings page but does now allow for any user input. The search is not usable to the end user and distracts them from the purpose of this page to either upgrade/start a trial or manage their existing subscription. 
 
![image](/uploads/c6b9f222d0cb62d900c7cfca3187258f/image.png)
  
# Solution
The settings search bar should be removed from the in-app billings page.
 
Note: we do NOT need to run this as an experiment and this can simply be fixed in production.

title: Compliance pipeline configuration path validates only master branch
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

When setting compliance pipeline configuration path, the [validation api](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f977c348c28200677d457a5bf2585c19d5a0b05e/app/assets/javascripts/api.js#L799) checks if the file is present only in `master` branch.

The [default branch](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/branches/default.html) can be overridden at project / group / instance level.

The validation will therefore always fail when the default branch is not `master`. This will prevent the Group owner from creating a compliance pipeline configuration path.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

1. Override default branch to a branch other than `master`
2. Create a project that will have the compliance pipeline configuration path file defined
3. Create compliance pipeline configuration path file (for e.g. `.compliance-gitlab-ci.yml` in the project created in Set (2)
4. Create a Compliance framework and try setting compliance pipeline configuration path to the file created in Set (3)

Observe the validation fails, indicating file does not exist.

Thanks to @aregnery for creating a video outlining the problem:

https://www.loom.com/share/33435a3ef2bc4622b737cad82e024719

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

Setting of Compliance pipeline configuration fails when default branch is not `master`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

Validate Compliance pipeline configuration path in the compliance project's default branch

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

epic.title: Allow group owners to define compliance pipeline configurations at the group level

title: Add new MergeRequests::SyncCodeOwnerApprovalRulesWorker
description:
`MergeRequests::SyncCodeOwnerApprovalRules#execute` out of `MergeRequests::UpdateService#after_update` - we call it synchronously, but I don’t think it is strictly required to be sync.. it adds “only” 3 queries to an otherwise bare/empty repo (one without Code Owners) but for a project that does, it’ll add those 3 + (2x the number of CR rules that are new and thus aren’t currently applied to the MR) + (the number of rules where users list has been changed) + (the number of rules where the groups list has been changed)

Related to #325691

title: Improve scheduling for batched background migrations
description:
After initial production testing of batched migrations, we have a few improvements that can be made immediately.

#### Allow short variance when scheduling next job

* [X] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/58580

A current limitation of the `sidekiq-cron` scheduling is that it only polls for jobs once per minute. Since the interval between jobs is often configured at an even minute value, this results in the cron missing the execution of the next job by a matter of seconds.

In practice, we saw a migration with a configured interval of 2 minutes running jobs at mostly a 3 minute interval. In order to work around this problem, we can add a small variance when checking if the interval has elapsed since the last job. If we're within a reasonable window of the next execution (a few seconds), we should execute the job.

#### Increase timeout on `ExclusiveLease`

* [X] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/58578

We currently takeout an `ExclusiveLease` in the `BatchedBackgroundMigrationWorker` to ensure we only have single-thread execution of background jobs. The timeout for this lease is currently set at two times the job interval.

However, in a production incident where database response times could drop considerably, the lease could likely expire before the job has finished its work, resulting in multiple jobs executing in parallel. To avoid this add-on effect, we should increase the timeout on the lease to a more conservative value.

This shouldn't impact operation during normal execution, as the lease is released when the job finishes.

#### Make pause time configurable

* [X] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/58583

When processing a batched background migration, we have two batching values, the `batch_size` and `sub_batch_size`. The `batch_size` is used to find the boundaries for each background job that executes. The `sub_batch_size` is used inside the background job, to process the outer batch in small pieces to keep query times low.

This strategy seems to work well, and we include a small sleep between each sub batch, to slow operations on the database. However, there is an upper limit on `sub_batch_size` that is determined by execution time on the database. At the same time, we may be able to increase the overall `batch_size` by large amounts, especially when processing in off-peak hours.

Unfortunately, the more batches we process, the more time the job spends pausing between each individual query, which can ultimately dominate the total execution time of the job. We should make the pause time a configurable value too, so that we can increase or decrease as necessary.

title: Improve Maven response times for 404s
description:
Endpoint `HEAD /api/:version/groups/:id/-/packages/maven/*path/:file_name` 

### :doughnut: Context

The maven API file endpoints are [hammered](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/1ea4f2180d633c377c05fd88f41b9029) with requests.

Upon inspecting the response status for the last 24 hours, we get this:

![Screenshot_2021-04-02_at_17.41.29](/uploads/592b7bce424e780604c8a8d229856aa4/Screenshot_2021-04-02_at_17.41.29.png)

So it's safe to say that more than 75% of the traffic on those file endpoints don't get an actual file.

Why is it so?

This is coming from how `mvn` (the main client) works. When you setup multiple registries for your dependencies and pull them, `mvn` will loop on *each* registry and `knock, knock do you have package X`?

In other words, the GitLab maven package registry receives many requests for packages/files that are not hosted in GitLab but elsewhere. My guess is that the majority of them are in maven central but due to how `mvn` works, GitLab get "pinged" too.

### :bulb: Proposal (Friday's Crazy Idea #8649134)

Given that those `404`s account for more than 75% of the requests. What if we take a few moment to have a preliminary check:

* given a maven path (the parameters we receive on the file endpoints), does a `Packages::Maven::Metadatum` record exists?
   * If no, we can right away reply `404`s.
   * If yes, execute the actual endpoint logic as it is today.

That's a simple existence check. There is no authentication, authorization checks. There is no queries to the packages table. It's just a simple answer to a simple question: does the path `my/path/bananas` exists in the table?

Why can we take the luxury of checking the `packages_maven_metadata` table first? One word: size. The `packages_maven_metadata` table is not a busy one such as `projects` or `packages`. We thus have way less records = scanning that table with a maven path is super fast.

Actually, I'm thinking that this could be the explanation why [the instance level endpoints are faster than the project level endpoints](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326094).

title: Update Debian group level endpoints urls
description:
### Problem

Here are the group level debian API endpoits:

```shell
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/Release.gpg(.:format) - The Release file signature
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/Release(.:format) - The unsigned Release file
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/InRelease(.:format) - The signed Release file
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/:component/binary-:architecture/Packages(.:format) - The binary files index
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/packages/debian/pool/:component/:letter/:source_package/:file_name(.:format) - The package
```

This is not following the proper [documented prefix](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/packages.html#rate-limits-on-gitlabcom).

### Solution

Change the endpoints to:

```shell
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/-/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/Release.gpg(.:format) - The Release file signature
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/-/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/Release(.:format) - The unsigned Release file
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/-/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/InRelease(.:format) - The signed Release file
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/-/packages/debian/dists/*distribution/:component/binary-:architecture/Packages(.:format) - The binary files index
GET /api/:version/groups/:id/-/packages/debian/pool/:component/:letter/:source_package/:file_name(.:format) - The package
```

title: DAST passive scan rule takes significant amount of time
description:
### Summary

While scanning [nextcloud](https://hub.docker.com/_/nextcloud) scan times run excessively long. This appears to be due to a poorly performing [regex](https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/main/zap/src/main/resources/org/zaproxy/zap/resources/config.xml#L76) (html_mailto)

nextcloud returns very large javascript bodies which this regex is run against for every response.



### Steps to reproduce

```
docker pull nextcloud:19-fpm-alpine
docker run -e SQLITE_DATABASE=nextcloud -e NEXTCLOUD_ADMIN_USER=admin -e NEXTCLOUD_ADMIN_PASSWORD=XXX -e NEXTCLOUD_TRUSTED_DOMAINS=vulnapp -d -p 8080:80 nextcloud

...
export img=`docker ps | grep nextcloud | awk -F " " '{print $NF}'`
docker run -ti --rm --link ${img}:vulnapp -v "$PWD/session":/home/zap/.ZAP_D/session -v $(pwd)/wrk:/zap/wrk:rw -v "$PWD":/output dast /analyze -t "http://vulnapp/" -j --full-scan true --auth-url "http://vulnapp/login" --auth-username-field="user" --auth-password-field="password" --auth-submit-field="submit-form" --auth-username="admin" --auth-password="XXX" -d --auth-exclude-urls "http://vulnapp/logout"
```

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

I am still tracking down the passive scan plugin(?) that loads this xml and scans the response bodies, but it's called from: `https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/main/zap/src/main/java/org/zaproxy/zap/extension/pscan/PassiveScanThread.java#L227` 

with the error being reported here: `https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/blob/main/zap/src/main/java/org/zaproxy/zap/extension/pscan/PassiveScanThread.java#L251`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

It does not warn that the passive scan takes too long, because the passive scans should not take long.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

```
2431457 [ZAP-PassiveScanner] WARN org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscan.PassiveScanThread  - Passive Scan rule html_mailto took 8 seconds to scan http://vulnapp/apps/workflowengine/js/workflowengine.js?v=www.google.com%3A80%2F application/javascript 1367286

2448187 [ZAP-PassiveScanner] WARN org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscan.PassiveScanThread  - Passive Scan rule html_mailto took 8 seconds to scan http://vulnapp/apps/workflowengine/js/workflowengine.js?v=www.google.com%2Fsearch%3Fq%3DOWASP%2520ZAP application/javascript 1367286

2468073 [ZAP-PassiveScanner] WARN org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscan.PassiveScanThread  - Passive Scan rule html_mailto took 8 seconds to scan http://vulnapp/core/js/dist/main.js?v=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F application/javascript 1443963
2477345 [ZAP-PassiveScanner] WARN org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscan.PassiveScanThread  - Passive Scan rule html_mailto took 8 seconds to scan http://vulnapp/core/js/dist/main.js?v=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%3A80%2F application/javascript 1443963
```

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

I've opened an upstream bug report: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/6509

Work around is to disable passive scan tags:
```

pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(0).enabled=false -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(1).name=html_tag_form -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(1).type=TAG -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(1).config=Form -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(1).enabled=false -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(2).name=html_tag_password -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(2).type=TAG -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(2).config=Password -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(2).enabled=false -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(3).name=html_type_hidden -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(3).type=TAG -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(3).config=Hidden -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(3).enabled=false -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(4).name=html_type_upload -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(4).type=TAG -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(4).config=Upload -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(4).enabled=false -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(5).name=html_tag_object -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(5).type=TAG -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(5).config=Object -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(5).enabled=false -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(6).name=html_tag_script -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(6).type=TAG -config pscans.autoTagScanners.scanner(6).config=Script -config title: Geo: Mass deletion of large proportion of projects leads to runaway `geo:geo_repository_destroy` queue
description:
## Problem

* I mass inserted 500k fake project records to test a DB query.
* The secondary created a registry record for each project record (good).
* I mass deleted all fake project records, leaving me with 51 real projects.
* The secondary `Geo::Secondary::RegistryConsistencyWorker` enqueues 10k `GeoRepositoryDestroyWorker` per run (up to every 5 seconds, or a bit less if execution takes more than 5 seconds)

On my dev setup, `geo:geo_repository_destroy` is drained slower than it is added to, so the queue grows uncontrolled until the number of deleteable registry records is somewhat lower than the remaining number of registry records.

## Possible solutions

Idea: Make `RegistryConsistencyWorker` mark registries for deletion instead of enqueuing jobs. Then add a worker to delete registries which are marked for deletion. Note this requires a new field on all registry tables. Weight 4.

Another idea: Make `RegistryConsistencyWorker` delete synchronously, with one mass delete query (it's already capped at a batch of 10000), since currently `GeoRepositoryDestroyWorker` jobs enqueued by `RegistryConsistencyWorker` do not have the ability to find and delete the repository anyway. Weight 1.

## Workaround

A workaround is to delete the `geo:geo_repository_destroy` queue when it grows too large, but this may delete jobs enqueued by other sources (events), and therefore can lead to orphaned repository data on the secondary.

title: Implement basic Virtual Scrolling in Merge Request Diffs
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

When rendering very large MRs, the performance deteriorates immensely.

Theoretically, by removing the number of nodes in the page we can reduce the amount of watchers/getters/setters currently on the page and the rendering load of having so many DOM nodes.

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

Large Merge Requests perform better.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
1. Use virtual scrolling to hide Diff Files distant from the viewport
   * Hiding can be partial (only parts of the diff file are removed) or complete (the whole diff file is removed)
1. Render diff files as user scrolls through the page, never noticing the are being rendered as they go.

### Further details

Performance bottlenecks and impact to monitor:

Goals:

* TBT metric going down
* Memory usage going down
* No sluggishness while user scrolls
* No feature is broken
* (ideally) Native browser search can still find important parts, like the diff lines or notes.

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->


### Availability & Testing

title: Halt unnecessary polling requests when the page visibility is hidden
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal 

<!-- Use this section to explain the feature and how it will work. It can be helpful to add technical details, design proposals, and links to related epics or issues. -->

In an effort to make our Merge Request pages be as efficient and less prone to hog resources unnecessarily, we should do an assessment of the requests currently being triggered when the user moves away from the tab and which ones should be kept going.

### Goals

* Reduce unnecessary load on the servers
* Reduce possible side-effects of memory leaks of tabs left opened for a long time leading to overblown memory usage

### Further context

A few milestones ago we looked into this in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210377

We ended up calculating a hidden interval for smartInterval requests.

> hiddenInterval: window.gon?.features?.widgetVisibilityPolling && 360 * 1000,

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/29318/diffs#4b8bd0c53339a8aa29374625faad0816a5c6d051

I believe it currently sits at 1x per 6min. 

Now, do all requests currently actively polling the MR page use this smartInterval implementation? :thinking: 

### Requests


**Overview tab**

| Request            | Frequency when Tab visible        | Frequency when Tab hidden                               |
| ------------------ | --------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------- |
| widget.json        | 10, 20, 40 seconds...             | 0                                                       |
| notes              | 6 seconds                         | 0                                                       |
| cached_widget.json | 10, 20, 40 seconds...             | 0                                                       |
| test_reports.json  | 1 every time page becomes visible | 0                                                       |
| sast_reports.json  | 3 seconds (from sentry)           | Seems to stop reporting completely and never come back? |
| graphql: getState  | *2 up to 4 minutes                | *2 up to 6 minutes                                      |

**Changes tab**

| Request                     | Frequency when Tab visible | Frequency when Tab hidden |
| --------------------------- | -------------------------- | ------------------------- |
| notes                       | 6 seconds                  | 0                         |
| sast_reports                | ?                          | ?                         |
| dependency_scanning_reports | ?                          | ?                         |
| graphql: getState           | ?                          | ?                         |
| widget                      | ?                          | ?                         |
| tp2 (sentry)                | ?                          | ?                         |

#### Note

The big 3 are notes, dependency_scanning_reports, and sast_reports which are nearly constant.

The others may be triggered by some activity of me toggling back and forth between tabs to take notes and observer network traffic.

You can also reference the Feature Proposal Template (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/Feature%20proposal.md) for additional details to consider adding to this issue. Additionally, as a data oriented organization, when your feature exits planning breakdown, consider adding the `What does success look like, and how can we measure that?` section.

title: Add batched background migration information to admin panel
description:
The current admin panel in the app displays information about the status of background jobs. With the addition of the batched background migration framework, this panel will no longer capture the full status of ongoing background migrations.

Additionally, as part of our no-downtime upgrade process, we recommend for background migrations to be finished before beginning the upgrade. If the jobs do not have time to properly finish through sidekiq, any cleanup jobs will execute inline when post-deployment migrations are run.

In order to roll out primary key conversion migrations to self-hosted installations, we should update the panel to also include information about these migrations. This will also be helpful for us to monitor the status of ongoing migrations on GitLab.com.

Items left todo

- [x] Add the retry button to failed migrations

title: Settings search results don't filter out all sections
description:
### Summary

When searching in the User Settings, filtering the page down to show only the results does not remove all un-matched page elements. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to your [profile settings](https://gitlab.com/-/profile) or [preferences](https://gitlab.com/-/profile/preferences) 
1. Search for a string that you know won't match anything on the page, for example `gj28uw2398`
1. Notice the structure of the page is inconsistent with other settings pages, some elements are still visible on the page and not filtered from the results

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Some elements that do not match the search term are still visible

<details>![Screen_Shot_2021-04-01_at_1.01.07_PM](/uploads/bf455a2d155b9f2500996adeaf0cb23d/Screen_Shot_2021-04-01_at_1.01.07_PM.png)
<summary>Screenshot of Profile > Preferences</summary>
</details>

title: Geo: Verification failures over text limit
description:

```
PG::CheckViolation: ERROR:  new row for relation "snippet_repositories" violates check constraint "snippet_repositories_verification_failure_text_limit"
DETAIL:  Failing row contains (88, 18166, @snippets/67/c1/67c1e692c9fd59521dd2cbab319e40441bbd60a30b8e125c..., 28, 2021-04-01 16:19:23.396216+00, 2021-04-01 15:18:29.396278+00, null, Error during verification: 2:accessor call: route repository acc..., 3, 2021-04-01 15:18:29.352924+00).
```

This results in the actual verification failure being obscured to admins.

We already truncate the string to 255: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/c032ad6d69e4bf2317bd864d48dff06e5e82e396/ee/lib/gitlab/geo/verification_state.rb#L331

Was I was off by one, and should have done 254?

title: Alignment problem with error banner.
description:
Following a [discussion in slack](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CETG54GQ0/p1617250168155300), there's a bit of confusion on which banner width to use.

![image](/uploads/d58a47d1d715c56bae18276608847c11/image.png)

Per [documentation](https://design.gitlab.com/components/alert/#global) we should expand this to the full width of the page.

> A global alert impacts the entire experience, is full-width, and is placed directly below the navigation bar. For example, after a user has authenticated an alert appears that states, “Your subscription has expired.”

See originating issue for context. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/237905

## Proposal
| In issue - Normal | Wide | Project / Group viewer |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![Frame_65](/uploads/1b3931c30de531a8ba45273b7c6c5a73/Frame_65.png) | ![Frame_66](/uploads/9d6d0d5b3bbc6ba4772f8e2eb4f7dff8/Frame_66.png) | ![Frame_67](/uploads/c86429296969f17cd99f343b9d45ffc9/Frame_67.png) |

## Implementation plan

For this issue we will *only* take care of the `Open registration is enabled on your instance` and `Auto DevOps pipeline has been enabled` alerts. The rest will be taken care of in a follow-up issue. 

1. Create a new HAML partial (`_global_alert.html.haml`). '
   - Will handle all of the styling
   - Will have a `yield` statement for the alert content
   - Will have a `title` local for the title
   - Will have a `variant` local for the alert type
1. Refactor [app/views/layouts/header/_registration_enabled_callout.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/layouts/header/_registration_enabled_callout.html.haml) to use this partial
1. Refactor [app/views/shared/_auto_devops_implicitly_enabled_banner.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/shared/_auto_devops_implicitly_enabled_banner.html.haml) to use this partial
1. Open up follow-up issues to refactor the rest of the global alerts

title: Package managers API: permissions incoherence
description:
### Situation

Follow up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/58329

The group level maven endpoints require:
* `read_group` on the target group
* `read_package` on the project hosting the package

The group level nuget endpoints require:
* `read_package` on the target group
* `read_package` on the project hosting the package

nuget APIs are more restrictive than maven.

### Solution

Use the maven permission checks as a baseline for all group level endpoints.

title: Fix the required permission at the Group level for pulling packages.
description:
### Summary

With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/57600, we modified the maven package finder to improve its efficiency.

One of the improvements made was to implement https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/287638 by using an [existing finder helper](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/app/finders/concerns/packages/finder_helper.rb).

This causes an issue for the group level maven api.

Given this situation:

Group    ->   Subgroup     ->    Project

Before https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/57600:

Reporters of `Subgroup` could pull packages from `Project` by using the group level endpoint and targeting `Group`.

How is that possible?

* Users [need](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/lib/api/maven_packages.rb#L149) the `read_group` permission on the target group (`Group`).
    * This is [granted](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/app/policies/group_policy.rb#L95-97) by the group policy which basically says if a user has access to any of the subprojects, it has access to the root group with the `read_group` permission.
* Users [need](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/lib/api/maven_packages.rb#L153) the `read_package` permission on the project (`Project`).
    * This is granted by the usual role system where reporters of `Subgroup` will be reporters on the contained projects.
    * The above will [grant](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/app/policies/project_policy.rb#L261) the `read_package` permission


After https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/57600:

The same scenario will now fail.

* Users [need](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/lib/api/maven_packages.rb#L149) the `read_group` permission on the target group (`Group`).
    * Same as before
* Users [need](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f043ace969a4c1488b9b14373ea86b0c49182ed4/lib/api/maven_packages.rb#L153) the `read_package` permission on the project (`Project`).
    * Same as before
* In addition, users [need](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f4e9203f9567e233d3269b177e2634f64271466e/app/finders/concerns/packages/finder_helper.rb#L14) `read_package` on the target group (`Group`)
    * This is a new check
    * `read_package` on groups is only [granted](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f4e9203f9567e233d3269b177e2634f64271466e/app/policies/group_policy.rb#L132) to direct reporters (or public groups).
        * Reporters of `Subgroup` will not have this :boom: 




### Possible fixes

1. We could grant `read_package` the [same way](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f4e9203f9567e233d3269b177e2634f64271466e/app/policies/group_policy.rb#L96) that `read_group` is granted for a Group but that will open things too much to my taste. This increases the risk of leaking private objects.
1. We can modify the package finder helper to enforce `read_group` instead of `read_package`.
    * This would mimic the same set of permissions checked for Maven APIs before the MR.
    * The package finder helper is also used by NuGet packages but this is fine as nuget APIs directly [check](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f4e9203f9567e233d3269b177e2634f64271466e/lib/api/concerns/packages/nuget_endpoints.rb#L60) the `read_package` permission on the group.

Solution (2.) is the best one.

title: Run authenticated scans against web applications that use popup login forms
description:
### Problem to solve 

Many websites use a popup/modal for the login form. The process to login is navigation to the home page, click sign in, and enter the username/password into the popup.

This issue proposes adding an option to the authentication configuration to allow users to click an element prior to entering the login details.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

When Browserker navigations to `AuthDetails.LoginURL`, it should check to see if the new configuration value `AuthDetails.LoginSelector` exists on the page. If it is present, the selector should be clicked. The resulting form should be filled out by the normal Browserker authentication process.

This should work for manual and auto login attempts.

Update: The user should be able to supply a list of selectors. Each selector will be clicked on. This allows user to click to open the menu, then click on sign in, as an example.

### Documentation

Please update the Browserker configuration documentation.

### What is the type of buyer?

[Gold/Ultimate](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#three-tiers)

### Implementation plan

- [x] After loading the login URL in `captureLoginPage`, actions should be followed using `crawler.Process`
- [x] For each new processed action, new Navigations should be captured
- [x] A section should be added to the report for each login action step
- [x] Add an end-to-end test to ensure that users can log in with popup login forms
- [x] Likely have to adjust an end to end test fixture (pancakes?) to have a login form
- [x] Add documentation for the feature in the browser-based DAST configuration section.

Assigning a weight of `5`.

title: Support converting multiple columns in a single migration
description:
As part of the effort to convert primary keys to `bigint`, we discovered some tables have more than one column that needs to be migrated. For example, `ci_job_artifacts` has both the `id` column and the `job_id` column (foreign key referencing `ci_builds`) which need to be converted to `bigint`.

We need to support this, to prevent having to make more than one pass over the table. This change includes updating both the trigger and background migration code to support setting multiple columns.

epic.title: Improve background migrations for primary key conversions

title: [DevOps Adoption] Reduce data processing frequency from "daily" to "weekly"
description:
### Problem to solve

DevOps Adoption data collection has been performed daily since https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292516.  However, now we want to start collecting numeric data instead of simple booleans.  This will probably involve a greater volume of data processing.  With booleans we don't need to re-collect data once a feature is marked as `true`.  However, with numeric data we need to continue re-collecting data unless a feature is at `100%`.  We should minimize the potential impact of this greater processing volume.

### Proposal

DevOps Adoption data should be re-calculated weekly (instead of daily) per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326008#note_541187577.

*Preperation Phase*
- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)

- [x] Test on staging

- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default))

- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` by pinging `@sre-oncall`
  - In `#g_delivery` by pinging `@release-managers`

- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com (22:00  UTC as announced in https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1617827858325000)

*Partial Rollout Phase*
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour (`/chatops run feature set 10 --actors gldropdown_branches true`)

- [ ] Verify behaviour (See Beta Groups) and add details with screenshots as a comment on this issue


**Global Availability** ([More Info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change))
*(Please Note that Beta,Alpha and General Availability (GA) are handled on a product level and not the feature-flag)*
<!-- The next checkboxes are probably only needed for high visibility and/or critical rollouts. Please refer to the official documentation linked above for more clarification -->

- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.

- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com

- [x] Make the feature flag enabled by default i.e. Change `default_enabled` to `true`

- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)

- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled

- [ ] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel


**Cleanup**

This is an __important__ phase, that should be either done in the next Milestone or as soon as possible. For the cleanup phase, please follow our documentation on how to  [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up).

<!-- The checklist here is to keep track of it's status for stakeholders -->
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled

- [x] Remove `:feature_name` feature flag
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository
    - [ ] Create a Changelog Entry

- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running this chatops command in `#production` channel `/chatops run feature delete some_feature`.

**Final Step**

- [ ] Close this rollout issue for the feature flag after the feature flag is removed from the codebase.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab gldropdown_branches false
```

title: Stop changing the vuex value outside vuex for state.approvals.settings
description:
The following discussion from !57844 should be addressed:

    > **question:** I know that this is the pattern of this file but... I think we are changing the vuex value outside vuex here :confused: This is probably not picked up by the devtools/linters because is a child property but it looks like that settings come straight from vuex: `settings: (state) => state.approvals.settings`

    >

title: Extract Ci::EnqueueJobService
description:
## Problem

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56492#note_529230865 we highlighted the need to add a generalized way to enqueue jobs. We seem to do it slightly differently in 

* `Ci::PlayBuildService`
* `Ci::PlayBridgeService`
* ~~`Ci::RetryJobService`~~ --> [Follow-up](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383602)
* `Ci::Pipeline#reset_source_bridge!` (!60376) (Optional: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60376#note_564911366)

and this could cause problems if the logic differs.

When a job is enqueued we always need to:

- assign the current user to it
- pass in any variables
- enqueue the job consistently (should we always use optimistic locking)?
- call `Ci::AfterRequeueJobService` to run the side-effects if enqueue is successful

## Solution

Extract a `Ci::EnqueueJobService` that does the above and will be reused in 

* `Ci::PlayBuildService`
* `Ci::PlayBridgeService`
* ~~`Ci::RetryJobService`~~ --> [Follow-up](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383602)
* `Ci::Pipeline#reset_source_bridge!` (!60376) (Optional: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60376#note_564911366)

## Follow-up
(2022-11-21) The code for `Ci::RetryJobService` recently updated such that `Gitlab::OptimisticLocking.retry_lock(job, name: 'retry_build', &enqueue)` no longer runs.  This operation was replaced with `Ci::PipelineCreation::StartPipelineService.new(job.pipeline).execute`.  Determined that it does not require a refactor at this time. See [follow-up](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/383602).

## Implementation

| ~backend  | MR |
| ------ | ------ |
| Extracts `Ci::EnqueueJobService` and reuses it in `Ci::PlayBuildService`, `Ci::PlayBridgeService`, and `Ci::Pipeline#reset_source_bridge!` | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/104454 |

title: The number of SQL queries in Ci::CreatePipelineService
description:
This issue is created based on these 3 issues:

- [API endpoint POST /projects/:project_id/trigger/pipeline executes more than 100 SQL queries](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/20758)
- [API endpoint POST /projects/:id/pipeline executes more than 100 SQL queries](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/20711)
- [Controller Projects::PipelinesController#create executes more than 100 SQL queries](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/20784)

In those issues, we try to investigate why those endpoints have more than 100 SQL queries. We realized that all three issues use the same service `Ci::CreatePipelineService`. And we decided to handle them all in this single issue. ([Slack discussion](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C013PRNRK0X/p1617102467057700))

Note :exclamation: => We are currently working on [moving pipeline processing to async](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/57589), and we think that can also help this issue.

---

Some reference => https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/321695

---

Track: https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/31d8fcc73a71895dca3d25d0efe91f91

title: Improve recipients validation on EmailsOnPushService
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55550 we introduced an advanced validation for the recipients field. The validation checks that the number of email addresses in the field is not higher than the limit (currently 750).

- Currently we consider any string containing an `@` as a valid email address. We should review this validation and consider adding a more strict one like `Devise.email_regexp`. (Suggested in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55550#note_541829797)
- We only validate the presence of `recipients`, but should also verify that we have at least one valid recipient. (Suggested in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55550#note_542114593)
- We currently send the whole list of recipients including invalid ones to the worker that sends the emails. We can consider just sending valid ones.

title: Move Project#disabled_services to Service#disabled_services_names
description:
### Description

Follow-up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/57556#note_539758559, `Service` model has all the information related to the available integrations but `Project` model has the information about the disabled integrations.

We should move the code from `Project#disabled_services` to `Service#disabled_services_names`.

title: Trial form: Pre-fill phone number field based on country selected.
description:
## Problem
Defined in [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5699).

## Proposed solution
#### MVC Approach
*  Update the telephone field with the country prefix regardless of the values the user may or may not have entered into the phone number field, i.e. we delete all values a replace it with only the new prefix.
* If a user deletes the prefix and simply enters a telephone number then we respect/trust their manual input
* Per Dallas' findings [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326452#note_542083281) we can add further validation of acceptable symbols and require the phone number length to be between 7 and 15 characters.

To support this MVC, we would move the country field above the phone number in the form. We could then use the input data to start pre-filling the phone number field with the dialing code. Users should be able to edit this dialing code if needed. (Example below):

| Before | After |
| ------ | ------ |
|![image](/uploads/6ce3a8ddf30fa0d6aedd4168da629cf5/image.png)| ![trialFormPhoneField](/uploads/c6896a4fda70555becf3113ab1b0579d/trialFormPhoneField.gif) |
| No country dial code | Adding country dial code |

#### Interaction
Changing the country value  will reset the form but the prefix remain editable:

![phoneFieldTrial](/uploads/5d2777aa97eb9766559958c1d86b5136/phoneFieldTrial.gif)


## How do we measure success
* Observe an increased sign-up rate in the trial flow.
* Decrease in time to completion.

epic.title: Verify trial flow telephone number field and improve field completion.

title: Performance optimization for `EnvironmentFinder`
description:
## Description

Often `EnvironmentFinder` causes performance issue, like https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325552. In the past, we discussed a couple of times that we should refactor this finder due to the bunch of performance issue by the unnecessarily complicated functionalities (Also, it's [very old](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/commit/9d7c5e75841eff48217487b3acda56cf265a2aef)), however, we've not done any actual action yet (AFAIK). Maybe it's good time to revisit this issue.

There is also inconsistency in code that there is no SSOT facility to fetch-and-filter environments i.e. some places use the finder, the other places directly access `Environment` model without using the finder. So that the performance issue tends to appear sparsely across different domains. Ideally, Release group provides a SSOT facility and we keep maintaining the finder with decent optimization for the other domains.

title: Revert "Allow reporters to run jobs that deploy to an environments if they are explicitly listed"
description:
## Problem

We should consider reverting the https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225482 feature. As we [discussed with a customer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/account-management/pre-sales/finra/-/issues/2), it turned out that the proposed solution won't work for them. They need more strategic permission/resource control, such as [Group-level permissions config for Protected Environments](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215888).

The main problem is that this feature is conceptually broken due to the environment centric approch. It doesn't respect the system-level [CI permissions and GitLab RBAC](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html), and result in skipping some important permission checks. This is simply hard to be used in a large organization because the permissions given to the operator group is insufficient in most of the cases, for example, operators (as reporter) can't access to the runner's setting for production deployment, where they should have an access. We should take into account of the CI resource boundary for operators, instead of looking at only job execution.

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323794 for more information.

## Proposal

Revert [Allow reporters to run jobs that deploy to an environments if they are explicitly listed
](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225482) (In documentation, [Environment access by group membership](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/protected_environments.html#environment-access-by-group-membership)). Specifically, the following MRs:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/38188 (Implementation)
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/39733 (Documentation)

[[UPDATE 05 Jul 2021]](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326447#note_618457390)

>>>
Sadly, we don't have a viable alternative solution in this case. If we address this problem properly, https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/1896 or https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/280534 should be addressed instead, however, this requires many effort (probably that's the reason why we fell back to [the workaround feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215888)).

I realized that the feature in question can also be combined with [the group-level protected environments](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215888) to effectively prevent operators from accessing repositories while still allowing them to execute deployment jobs (This still doesn't resolve [the problem on CI/CD resource management](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326447#problem) so I'm skeptical how this can fit in an actual enterprise org). But this specific access control *might* be required by [a prospect](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331085#note_613842171), so it'd be better NOT to revert this feature now. We should consider the revert after the https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/1896 or https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/280534 has been addressed.

In that sense, I'll mark this issue as blocked by these issues.
>>>

## Related

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215888
